Award.AwardTitle: SCH: INT: Collaborative Research: A Self-Adaptive Personalized Behavior Change System for Adolescent Preventive Healthcare

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The majority of morbidity and mortality during adolescence is preventable and related to behaviors such as substance use and vehicle-related injuries. Most adolescents visit a healthcare provider once a year, providing an ideal opportunity to integrate behavioral health screening into clinical care. Although the majority of adolescent health problems are amenable to behavioral intervention, few health information technology interventions have been integrated into adolescent care. With complementary theoretical advances (social-cognitive theories of behavior change) and technology advances (intelligent narrative-centered learning environments, user modeling, and machine learning), the field is now well positioned to design health behavior change systems that can realize significant impacts on behavior change for adolescent preventive health.

Computationally-enabled models of behavior change hold significant promise for adolescent healthcare. The objective of the proposed research is to design, implement, and investigate INSPIRE, a self-adaptive personalized behavior change system for adolescent preventive health. INSPIRE will utilize a social-cognitive theory of behavior change built around a tight feedback loop in which a narrative-centered behavior change environment will produce improved behaviors in patients, and the resulting patient outcome data will be used by a reinforcement learning optimization system to learn refined computational behavior change models. With a focus on risky behaviors and an emphasis on substance use, adolescents will interact with INSPIRE to develop an experiential understanding of the dynamics and consequences of their substance use decisions. A unique feature of INSPIRE afforded by recent advances in machine learning will be its ability to optimize health behavior change at both the individual and population levels. At the individual level, INSPIRE will utilize a patient behavior model to personalize its behavior change narratives for individual adolescents. It will customize interactions based on an adolescent's goals and affective models. At the population level, INSPIRE will utilize reinforcement learning to adapt its narrative generation system to systematically increase its ability to improve two types of outcomes: behavior change and self-efficacy. The project will culminate with an experiment conducted with a fully implemented version of INSPIRE at outpatient clinics within the UC San Francisco Department of Pediatrics, Benioff Children's Hospital.

It is anticipated that INSPIRE interventions will yield two types of outcomes: 1) improved health behavior through significant reductions in adolescent risky behavior, relative to standard of care; and 2) increased self-efficacy with respect to adolescents' ability to make good decisions about their health behaviors, relative to standard of care. Designed for natural integration into clinic workflow, interoperability with EHR and patient portal systems, and security and privacy requirements, INSPIRE will report patient behavior change summaries to healthcare providers. Through multi-platform deployments supporting laptop, desktop, tablet, and mobile computing devices, INSPIRE will serve as an empowering tool for adolescents, making them full participants in their own wellbeing. It will also enable researchers to run behavior analytics to investigate which properties of alternate interventions contribute most effectively to behavior change outcomes. Going forward, it is anticipated that INSPIRE will provide a testbed for a broad range of behavior change research and serve as the foundation for next-generation personalized preventive healthcare through computationally-enabled behavior change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of morbidity and mortality during adolescence is preventable and related to behaviors such as substance use and risky vehicle use. Most adolescents visit a healthcare provider once a year, providing an ideal opportunity to integrate behavioral health screening into clinical care. Although the majority of adolescent health problems are amenable to behavioral intervention, few health information technology interventions have been integrated into adolescent care. With complementary theoretical advances (social-cognitive theories of behavior change) and technology advances (intelligent narrative-centered learning environments, machine learning), the field is now well positioned to design health behavior change systems that can realize significant impacts on behavior change for adolescent preventive health.

Computationally-enabled models of behavior change hold significant promise for adolescent healthcare. The objective of the project was to design, implement, and investigate INSPIRE, a self-adaptive personalized behavior change system for adolescent preventive health. INSPIRE utilizes a social-cognitive theory of behavior change in which the narrative-centered behavior change environment will produce improved behaviors. This will yield adolescent outcome data, which in the future, will be used by a reinforcement learning optimization system to learn refined computational behavior change models. The resulting models will inform the creation of the next generation of narrative-centered behavior change environments and produce innovative computational theories of behavior change. The project had three major thrusts:

1. Design, develop, and iteratively refine an intelligent narrative-centered health behavior change environment for preventive adolescent health. Intelligent narrative generation integrates AI planning techniques and game technologies to dynamically generate immersive narratives whose plot structures, character interactions, and virtual worlds are synthesized at runtime. We created a narrative-centered health behavior change environment that targets risky behaviors in adolescents. Adolescents interacted with INSPIRE's narrative-centered health behavior change environment in an engaging interactive narrative featuring decision-making encounters with virtual characters in dilemma-focused interactions. The resulting data that was generated has set the stage for self-adaptive behavior change narrative generation for promoting health behavior change in adolescents.

2. Design, develop, and iteratively refine a machine learning-based patient behavior modeling system and behavior change optimization system. These systems are envisioned to operate at three levels. First, at the individual level, INSPIRE will utilize a patient behavior model to personalize its behavior change narratives for individual adolescents. It will customize interactions based on an adolescent's goals and affective models. Second, at the population level, INSPIRE will utilize reinforcement learning to adapt its narrative generation system to systematically improve its ability to improve two families of outcomes: behavior change and self-efficacy. Third, at the healthcare ecosystem level, INSPIRE will provide the health research community with health behavior change analytics capabilities. By investigating deep learning-based goal recognition and interactive narrative planning techniques, the project has established the foundation for behavior analytics for individuals, populations, and healthcare ecosystems. This will enable the investigation of which properties of self-adaptive narrative-centered behavior change systems contribute most effectively to adolescent behavior change outcomes.

3. Investigate the impact of the self-adaptive personalized behavior change system on patient behavior change in a study integrating clinic-based and home-based system deployment. The overarching hypothesis is that the narrative-centered behavior change intervention will result in 1) health behavior changes through significant reductions in adolescent risky behavior, and 2) increased self-efficacy with respect to adolescents' ability to make healthy decisions. To this end, the project saw the development and extensive piloting of the INSPIRE narrative-centered virtual environment for adolescent behavior change. 

The project has made significant contributions to adolescent health and to health technologies. First, the project has seen the design, development, and iterative refinement of an innovative narrative-centered health behavior change environment for adolescent preventive health that utilizes a social-cognitive theory of behavior change to foster improved behaviors in patients. With a focus on risky behavior and alcohol use, the behavior change environment was designed through a participatory design process involving close engagement with adolescents, yielding an intervention that scaffolds adolescents' self-regulatory processes, including goal setting, monitoring, strategy use, and reflection. Second, the project produced a systematic review of computer-based interventions designed to reduce alcohol use among adolescents and young adults. This review informed the design of behavior change strategies grounded in social-cognitive theory that can be readily delivered in narrative-centered health behavior change environments. Third, the project produced a set of empirical results demonstrating that adolescents find the narrative-centered behavior change environment to be engaging, believable, and personally relevant, while providing practice opportunities that can be translated to situations they encounter in their own lives.
